Submodules

real_fields.base_classes_methods module

class real_fields.base_classes_methods.RetrievePulsesRealFields(*args, f_range_fields=(None, None), **kwargs)

Bases: RetrievePulses

A Base-Class for reconstruction via real fields. Real fields need to be considered if multiple nonlinear signals are present in the same trace. A complex signal does not inherently express difference frequency generation. Because complex signals do not possess negative frequencies.

frequency

the frequencies correpsonding to pulse/gate-pulse

Type:

jnp.array

frequency_big

a large frequency axis needed for the signal field due to negative frequencies

Type:

jnp.array

time_big

the corresponding time axis to frequency_big

Type:

jnp.array

sk_big

correction values for FFT->DFT

Type:

jnp.array

rn_big

correction values for FFT->DFT

Type:

jnp.array

get_data(x_arr, frequency_exp, measured_trace)

Prepare/Convert data.

interpolate_signal(signal_t, measurement_info, axis_in, axis_out, batch_axes=-2)
class real_fields.base_classes_methods.RetrievePulsesFROGwithRealFields(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: RetrievePulsesRealFields, RetrievePulsesFROG

Overwrites the generation of the signal field in order to use real fields instead of complex ones.

get_gate_pulse(frequency, gate_f)

For crosscorrelation=True the actual gate pulse has to be provided.

calculate_signal_t(individual, tau_arr, measurement_info)

Calculates the signal field of a FROG in the time domain. Does so by using real fields instead of complex ones.

Parameters:

  • individual – Pytree, a population containing only one member. (jax.vmap over whole population)

  • tau_arr – jnp.array, the delays

  • measurement_info – Pytree, contains the measurement parameters (e.g. nonlinear method, interferometric, … )

Returns:

Pytree, contains the signal field in the time domain as well as the fields used to calculate it.

class real_fields.base_classes_methods.RetrievePulsesCHIRPSCANwithRealFields(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: RetrievePulsesRealFields, RetrievePulsesCHIRPSCAN

Overwrites the generation of the signal field in order to use real fields instead of complex ones.

calculate_signal_t(individual, phase_matrix, measurement_info)

Calculates the signal field of a Chirp-Scan in the time domain. Does so by using real fields instead of complex ones.

Parameters:

  • individual – Pytree, a population containing only one member. (jax.vmap over whole population)

  • phase_matrix – jnp.array, the applied phases

  • measurement_info – Pytree, contains the measurement parameters (e.g. nonlinear method, … )

Returns:

Pytree, contains the signal field in the time domain as well as the fields used to calculate it.
